questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive pain and swelling of her wrists and hands for the past 2 months. Her hands are stiff in the morning; the stiffness decreases as she starts her chores. She also reports early-morning neck pain at rest for the past 3 weeks. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilateral swelling and tenderness of the wrists, second, third, and fourth metacarpophalangeal joints; range of motion is limited by pain. There is no vertebral tenderness. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.8 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9800/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
44 mm/h


Serum



 Glucose
77 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


 Total bilirubin
0.7 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
33 U/L


 AST
24 U/L


 ALT
21 U/L


 Rheumatoid factor

positive


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis may be used as part of the workup of RA to rule out differentials such as septic arthritis and pseudogout in atypical presentations. This patient's presentation, however, is typical of RA.

B) INCORRECT:

Biologic DMARDs, such as the TNF-α inhibitor adalimumab, may be indicated as additional therapy if patients only have a partial response to conventional DMARD therapy. This patient has not yet received conventional DMARD therapy. In addition, contraindications to anti-TNF-α treatment (e.g., pregnancy, immunosuppression, tuberculosis) must be ruled out before therapy is initiated.

C) CORRECT:

Early-morning neck pain in a patient with RA should raise suspicion for atlantoaxial subluxation, a potentially life-threatening complication of RA that should prompt further diagnostic workup. Extension and flexion x-ray of the cervical spine is the initial diagnostic test of choice to evaluate patients for atlantoaxial instability. Diagnosis is established if the distance between the anterior arch of the atlas and the dens axis (i.e., the atlantodental interval) is increased to > 3 mm in a fully flexed position. MRI can further be used to visualize the cervical nerve roots and spinal cord. RA typically affects the cervical spine early in the course of the disease (the thoracic and lumbar spine are normally spared), resulting in inflammatory destruction of the ligaments of the atlantoaxial and intervertebral joints.

Acute antiinflammatory treatment with glucocorticoids and/or NSAIDs as well as long-term treatment with a conventional DMARD (e.g., methotrexate) should be initiated in this patient.
Image Description:

MRI cervical spine (T1-weighted; sagittal view) of a 64-year-old woman with a 12-year history of rheumatoid arthritis and increasing neck pain for 3 months

There are erosive changes to the odontoid process (dens; D). The distance between the dens and the anterior arch of the atlas (A) is widened due to (inflammatory) tissue proliferation ventrally to the dens (green overlay), causing posterior subluxation of the dens. This, in turn, has led to narrowing of the spinal canal between the dens and the posterior arch of the atlas, causing compression of the spinal cord (red overlay).
A syrinx is seen at C5–C7 (yellow overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of anti-Smith antibodies is recommended for the workup of rheumatic diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which may also manifest with polyarthritis and morning stiffness. Additionally, this patient's positive family history of the disease increases her risk. However, SLE does not typically manifest with positive rheumatoid factors. Furthermore, features such as serositis, photosensitivity, malar or discoid rash, fever, and fatigue would be expected in SLE. This patient most likely has RA, in which anti-Smith antibodies measurement has no role.

E) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest can diagnose potential interstitial pneumonia, which is a potential long-term complication of RA. However, this patient does not have signs or symptoms (such as dyspnea) that would suggest lung compromise.

F) INCORRECT:

A tuberculin skin test must be performed before initiating therapy with biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) because such agents cause immunosuppression and may result in reactivation of latent tuberculosis infection. Although biological DMARDs are used for rheumatoid therapy, they are generally not recommended as initial therapy.
questions.hint: This patient presents with classical features of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), such as morning stiffness that improves with activity, symmetrical polyarthralgia involving the metacarpophalangeal and wrist joints for > 6 weeks, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and a positive rheumatoid factor.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of intermittent pain and stiffness in her hands and feet. She reports that these episodes occur about three times a month after she wakes up and last for approximately one hour. The episodes are sometimes accompanied by fever and myalgia. She takes ibuprofen during the episodes, which provides sufficient pain relief. She had her last attack 5 days ago. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Her sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild swelling and tenderness of the wrists and the proximal interphalangeal joints of both hands. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of her hands is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Methotrexate (MTX) is a synthetic, conventional disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that is indicated as first-line pharmacotherapy for long-term treatment in patients with moderate to high disease activity. Early administration of DMARDs is crucial because joint damage occurs early in the disease course. DMARDs interfere with the inflammatory mechanisms of RA, which can potentially lead to remission. MTX is highly effective, well-tolerated, and inexpensive but has a slow onset of action (> 6 weeks). Therefore, short-term concomitant antiinflammatory treatment with glucocorticoids and/or NSAIDs is usually indicated during acute attacks. This patient's last acute attack ended five days ago, obviating the need for additional acute antiinflammatory treatment.

Adverse effects of MTX (e.g., stomatitis, pancytopenia, pneumonitis, elevated transaminases) can be reduced by administering salvage therapy (leucovorin rescue) 24–48 hours after MTX administration.

B) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone would be an empiric antibiotic treatment option for septic arthritis if arthrocentesis of the affected joint had revealed gram-negative cocci. Septic arthritis manifests with joint pain, fever, limited range of motion, and swelling, all of which are seen in this patient during the attacks. However, unlike RA, septic arthritis usually affects only a single large joint, and the pain and fever are typically severe and not self-limited. Because joint damage predisposes to infection, patients with rheumatoid arthritis are at increased risk of septic arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is a non-biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that is used in combination therapy for refractory RA or as monotherapy if the first-line treatment is contraindicated. Hydroxychloroquine is also the first-line treatment for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Given her family history of SLE, this patient is at increased risk of SLE. Arthritis symptoms and fever, both of which are seen in this patient, are common findings in SLE. However, she lacks other typical findings of SLE, such as malar rash and photosensitivity. In addition, arthritis in SLE is typically non-destructive, whereas the x-ray shows joint destruction in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Adalimumab is a biologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that is used as an adjunct long-term treatment option for patients who do not respond to the first-line monotherapy. However, since this patient has not yet received any form of treatment, adalimumab is not indicated at this point.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic or intra-articular prednisolone would be a treatment option for acute attacks of RA. However, this patient's last acute attack ended 5 days ago and she is currently asymptomatic. Glucocorticoids are not used for long-term treatment because of their extensive side effect profile and the availability of more effective alternatives that can alter the course of the disease.

F) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs, such as diclofenac, would be a good treatment option in case of an acute attack of RA. Even though diclofenac does not halt disease progression, it is effective in alleviating acute symptoms (pain, swelling). However, this patient is currently not symptomatic and long-term treatment needs to be initiated in order to prevent disease progression and further joint destruction.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a history of polyarthralgia with symmetrical pain and swelling as well as morning stiffness for > 6 weeks. The x-ray shows generalized osteopenia, marginal erosions, and narrowed joint spaces of the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and wrist joints. In addition, the distal interphalangeal joints are spared, which is typical for rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 4-month history of lethargy. She has had joint pain for the past 15 years and does not have a primary care physician. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 132/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor of the oral mucosa and nontender subcutaneous nodules on both elbows. The distal interphalangeal joints of both hands are flexed and the proximal interphalangeal joints appear hyperextended. Range of motion in the fingers is restricted. The liver span is 6 cm and the spleen tip is palpated 4 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
33%


Leukocyte count
1,800/mm3



Segmented neutrophils
35%


Lymphocytes
60%


Platelet count
130,000/mm3



Increased serum titers of which of the following is most specific for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anti-cyclical citrullinated peptide antibodies (anti-CCP antibodies) are a highly specific marker for RA (specificity > 90%). High anti-CCP antibody titers are also associated with a more aggressive disease course (e.g., erosive arthritis or extra-articular manifestations, such as rheumatoid nodules and Felty syndrome). Although rare, Felty syndrome can occur in severe, long-standing, seropositive RA. Increased destruction of platelets and RBCs by the enlarged spleen (hypersplenism) results in thrombocytopenia and low hematocrit, which may be further aggravated by anemia of chronic disease.

See “Serological testing in rheumatoid arthritis” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Smith antibodies (anti-Sm antibodies) are highly specific (≈ 90%) for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE is more common among women and can manifest with arthralgia, anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and splenomegaly. However, joint deformities are uncommon (< 10% of cases), and leukopenia in patients with SLE is typically the result of lymphopenia, not neutropenia. Moreover, further symptoms such as myalgias, photosensitivity, and/or a malar rash would be expected in SLE. Anti-Sm antibodies are not associated with RA.

C) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) can be seen in approximately 30–50% of patients with RA. However, ANAs are also found in a number of other autoimmune disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, inflammatory myopathies), and even in 25% of healthy individuals. Therefore, ANAs have low specificity for RA. Although the sensitivity of ANAs is higher in patients with RA and extra-articular manifestations (e.g., Felty syndrome), the specificity does not increase.

D) INCORRECT:

Although rheumatoid factor (RF) is present in 60–80% of patients with RA, this marker is not specific since it may also be seen in other autoimmune disorders (e.g., Sjogren syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, rheumatic fever), certain infectious diseases (e.g., syphilis, tuberculosis, infectious mononucleosis, infective endocarditis), sarcoidosis, pulmonary fibrosis, and/or chronic liver disease. RF can also be found in 3–5% of healthy individuals. The sensitivity of RF is higher in patients with RA and extra-articular manifestations (e.g., Felty syndrome), however, the specificity does not increase.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-U1 ribonucleoprotein antibodies (anti-U1 RNP antibodies) may be seen in 5–10% of patients with RA. However, anti-U1 RNP may also be seen in mixed connective tissue disease and occasionally in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, discoid lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Anti-U1 RNP antibodies are not a specific marker for RA.
questions.hint: A combination of chronic joint pain, swan neck deformities, subcutaneous nodules on the elbow (rheumatoid nodules), and Felty syndrome (arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia) in a middle-aged woman is consistent with rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain in both of her wrist joints and her fingers for the past 24 hours. She has a 6-month history of similar episodes, which are often associated with stiffness for about 90 minutes when she wakes up in the morning. She has hyperlipidemia and hypertension. Two years ago, she was diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease, for which she underwent treatment. Current medications include fenofibrate and amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Examination shows swelling and tenderness of the wrists and metacarpophalangeal joints bilaterally. Range of motion is decreased due to pain. There are subcutaneous, nontender, firm, mobile nodules on the extensor surface of the forearm, with the overlying skin appearing normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate acute treatment for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs such as indomethacin are used as first-line symptomatic treatment for patients with acute flares of RA. However, NSAIDs should be avoided in patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease, as these drugs are associated with an increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding. If necessary, NSAIDs may be administered only in combination with a proton pump inhibitor. Moreover, a different treatment reduces joint tenderness and pain more effectively than NSAID therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate (MTX) is the first-line disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) for patients with RA. MTX is effective at preventing and, in some cases, improving joint destruction from RA and should, therefore, be initiated as soon as RA is diagnosed. However, due to its long onset of action (weeks to months), MTX would not provide the fast-acting symptomatic relief this patient requires. Another drug would more effectively treat this patient's acute symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

Symptomatic treatment of acute flares of RA (i.e., episodes of increased disease activity) consists of temporary administration of antiinflammatory drugs such as glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisolone) and/or NSAIDs. A short course of glucocorticoids is more effective than NSAID therapy at reducing symptoms of inflammatory synovitis such as joint tenderness and pain. Glucocorticoids can either be administered systemically or via intraarticular injections (e.g., with triamcinolone acetonide). Glucocorticoids should be used at the lowest effective dose and only for short periods of time (< 3 months) to reduce the risk of their many adverse effects (e.g., hypertension, osteoporosis, infections).

In patients with peptic ulcer disease, the risk of gastrointestinal complications from glucocorticoids alone is low, which is why glucocorticoids are not contraindicated in this patient. However, in this patient group, glucocorticoids should not be combined with NSAIDs, because this significantly increases the rate of gastrointestinal complications.

D) INCORRECT:

The biologic adalimumab is used in patients with RA who still have moderate or severe disease activity after 3 months of DMARD therapy. Adalimumab would not be used as the initial treatment in a patient with an acute flare who has not yet received synthetic DMARD therapy yet.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D and calcium supplements are used to prevent osteoporosis in the course of long-term treatment for RA, however, these drugs would not be helpful in treating an acute flare.

F) INCORRECT:

Colchicine is used to treat gout. While gout can also manifest with joint pain and obesity is a risk factor for the disease, patients with acute flares of gout generally present with monoarthritis (most commonly in the big toe, knee, or thumb), while this patient has had pain and swelling in multiple joints over a period of several months.

G) INCORRECT:

Sulfasalazine is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) used in patients with RA that is often used during pregnancy. Sulfasalazine is not an appropriate treatment choice for a patient with an acute flare.
questions.hint: This patient presents with classic signs of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), including symmetrical joint pain and swelling (particularly affecting the metacarpophalangeal joints), morning stiffness, and rheumatoid nodules. Her current exacerbation of symptoms suggests an acute flare.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an increasingly painful swelling behind her right knee for the past 2 months. During this time, she has also had intermittent low-grade fevers and has been more fatigued than usual. She has not had any trauma to the knee. Over the past year, she has had occasional pain in her hands and wrists bilaterally. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She drinks one to two glasses of wine daily and occasionally more on weekends. Current medications include enalapril, metformin, and glimepiride. Her mother and older brother have osteoarthritis. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm nontender mass in the right popliteal fossa that becomes prominent when the knee is extended. There is mild swelling and redness of her right knee joint. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis (OA) can affect multiple joints, with a predilection for weight-bearing and high-use joints, such as the knees, hips, and wrist joints. Osteoarthritis of the knee is a common risk factor for the development of a Baker cyst and this patient's family history of osteoarthritis and frequent alcohol use put her at increased risk. However, this patient lacks other strong risk factors for OA (e.g., age > 55 years, severe obesity, positive trauma history, excessive joint use). Also, joint involvement in OA is typically isolated and asymmetrical, whereas this patient shows polyarticular and symmetrical involvement of her hands and wrists. Fever and fatigue are not characteristic of OA.

B) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic arthritis (PA) can manifest with symmetric polyarthritis or oligoarthritis of peripheral and axial joints. However, this patient lacks the typical skin findings (demarcated erythematous lesions and white scaling plaques) and nail changes (e.g., nail pitting, brittle nails) seen in psoriasis. While PA, like other arthritides, is a risk factor for the development of a Baker cyst, the involvement of finger joints in PA is more commonly characterized by a diffuse swelling of the entire digit (dactylitis/sausage digit) rather than the hand or wrist.

C) INCORRECT:

Although a popliteal artery aneurysm manifests with a mass in the popliteal fossa, the mass would be pulsatile on examination. This patient most likely has a Baker cyst, which, together with her history of polyarthritis (pain in the hands and wrists), low-grade fevers, and fatigue, is suggestive of a systemic inflammatory condition.

D) CORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is associated with synovial inflammation, which may result in excess production of synovial fluid, inflammatory joint effusion, and subsequently, formation of a Baker cyst. This patient presents with subtle features of RA, including polyarticular arthritis affecting the right knee and her finger and wrist joints, and constitutional symptoms (a history of low-grade fevers and fatigue), all of which make this condition the most likely diagnosis.

In adults, baker cysts commonly occur secondary to inflammatory diseases (such as RA), as well as degenerative (e.g., osteoarthritis), or traumatic (e.g. meniscal tears) joint conditions.

E) INCORRECT:

Gout can manifest with monoarticular inflammation of the knee (gonagra) and, in its chronic form, result in the formation of a Baker cyst as a sign of a chronic degenerative joint disorder. This patient has several risk factors for the development of gout, including diabetes, hypertension, and alcohol consumption. However, polyarticular involvement of the hands and wrists as the initial manifestation would be unusual. Furthermore, the affected joints in acute gout are typically exquisitely tender to palpation. Although polyarticular involvement can sometimes occur in chronic gout, tophi would likely be evident on physical examination.

F) INCORRECT:

Manifestations of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) include symmetrical polyarthritis, fever, and fatigue. However, arthritis in SLE is typically migratory (i.e., arthritic symptoms may disappear in one joint and appear in another within the same day). More importantly, while inflammatory arthritis is a risk factor for the development of Baker cysts, these cysts are not a common finding in patients with SLE.
questions.hint: A mass in the popliteal fossa that becomes prominent when the knee is extended is characteristic of a popliteal (Baker) cyst.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and swelling of his legs and feet for 6 weeks. During this time, he has felt like his eyes have been unusually puffy in the mornings and his urine has been frothy. He has hypertension and rheumatoid factor-positive rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications include amlodipine, methotrexate, and ibuprofen. He does not smoke. He has a history of chronic alcohol use. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 148/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor, periorbital edema, 2+ pedal edema, and ascites. He has swan-neck deformities and nodules on multiple fingers and swelling and restricted range of motion of bilateral knee joints. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
8.2 mg/dL


Prothrombin time
12 sec


Serum



 Albumin
2.8 g/dL


 Total bilirubin
1.0 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
80 U/L


 AST
20 U/L


 ALT
19 U/L


 Urea
18 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL


Urine



 Protein

3+


 WBCs
5–10/hpf


 RBCs
negative


 Bacteria
negative


Ultrasound of the liver and kidneys shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased hepatic albumin production suggests liver failure, which is often caused by chronic alcohol use and can manifest with edema, ascites, and hypoalbuminemia. This patient's liver function tests, however, are all within normal limits and ultrasound shows no hepatic abnormalities. In patients with nephrotic syndrome, hypoalbuminemia is caused by renal protein loss, which typically leads to a compensatory increase (rather than decrease) in hepatic albumin production.

B) INCORRECT:

One common adverse effect of amlodipine and other calcium channel blockers is pedal edema, which is present in this patient. However, amlodipine use does not explain this patient's periorbital edema, ascites, or proteinuria.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal deposition of AL amyloid suggests AL amyloidosis affecting the kidneys, which can also cause nephrotic syndrome. However, patients with AL amyloidosis typically have a plasma cell dyscrasia, such as multiple myeloma, which is not seen here.

D) CORRECT:

Chronic inflammatory processes such as rheumatoid arthritis can increase the production of serum amyloid A (SAA), an acute phase reactant. Reactive amyloidosis (AA amyloidosis) leads to the deposition of SAA in the kidneys, which commonly manifests with nephrotic syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal deposition of anti-dsDNA immune complex suggests lupus nephritis, which classically manifests with proteinuria, hematuria, and casts on urine microscopy, including red blood cell, hemoglobin, granular, tubular, or mixed casts. Although this patient does have proteinuria, he does not have other classic findings that suggest underlying systemic lupus erythematosus.
questions.hint: This patient's history of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis has played an important role in the development of nephrotic syndrome (pedal and periorbital edema, proteinuria). The frothy urine is likely secondary to proteinuria and the anemia is most likely due to chronic methotrexate use and/or anemia of chronic disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening pain and swelling of her left knee. For the past year, she has had pain in her knees and hands bilaterally and difficulties with movement for about an hour in the mornings. During this period, she has been feeling more fatigued and has also had frequent muscle aches and night sweats. She has been sexually active with a new partner for the past 4 weeks, and they use condoms inconsistently. She occasionally drinks alcohol. She drank 6 beers yesterday at her friend's birthday party. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. The left knee is erythematous, swollen, and tender; movement is restricted due to pain. There is swelling of the metacarpophalangeal joints and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally. Arthrocentesis of the knee with synovial fluid analysis shows a greenish, turbid fluid, a cell count of 68,000/mm3, and gram-negative diplococci. An x-ray of the affected knee is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Calcifications and osteolysis with moth-eaten appearance
Sunburst appearance of lytic bone lesions and Codman triangle
Irregularity or fragmentation of the tibial tuberosity
Punched-out lytic bone lesions with spiky periosteal appositions
Calcification of the meniscal and hyaline cartilage
Joint space narrowing and bone erosions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcifications and osteolytic lesions with a moth-eaten appearance can be seen in individuals with chondrosarcoma. This tumor typically manifests with night-time pain, local swelling, limited range of motion, and pathological fractures. Although chondrosarcoma can manifest with referred knee pain due to lesions in the pelvis or proximal femur, swelling and involvement of finger joints are not typically seen in this condition.
Image Description:

X-ray hips (AP view) of patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movement

A mixed lytic and blastic lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component. Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction suggest an aggressive lesion.

Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Lytic bone lesions with a sunburst appearance and a Codman triangle are typical signs of malignancy in cases of osteosarcoma. This tumor often affects the knee joint (distal femur, proximal tibia) and manifests with swelling, nocturnal pain, and decreased range of motion. While fever and nocturnal sweating may also occur (B symptoms), the bilateral hand involvement and morning stiffness cannot be explained by osteosarcoma.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP and lateral views) of a patient with osteosarcoma

An ill-defined cloud-like lesion with a wide zone of transition (green overlay) is seen in the distal femur. An aggressive type of periosteal reaction known as a Codman triangle (C) is visible medially. Additional aggressive periosteal reaction seen posteriorly has produced a sunburst pattern (S).

C) INCORRECT:

An irregularity or fragmentation of the tibial tuberosity is a diagnostic feature of Osgood-Schlatter disease, an overuse injury typically seen in adolescent boys. This condition manifests with anterior knee pain worsened by activity and proximal tibial swelling, but it is not associated with joint stiffness or limited range of motion. Moreover, bilateral hand involvement and constitutional symptoms cannot be explained by Osgood-Schlatter disease.
Image Description:

X-ray left knee (lateral view) of patient with history of recurrent minor trauma and chronic proximal anterior tibial pain

An ossified fragment (green overlay) is separate from the remainder of the tibial tuberosity, which shows an irregular margin (yellow overlay). There is thickening of the patellar tendon (red overlay) and pretibial soft tissues (blue overlay).

In conjunction with the clinical presentation, the radiographic features are consistent with Osgood-Schlatter disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Punched-out lytic bone lesions with spiky periosteal appositions can be detected in individuals with gout. Previously asymptomatic and undiagnosed hyperuricemia can be triggered by a sudden intake of a large amount of alcohol. While an acute gout attack may affect the small joints of the hands or the knees and manifest with swelling, pain, limited range of motion, and possibly fever, pathological x-ray findings would only be expected in longstanding chronic gout. Since this patient has no further features of chronic gout (e.g., bone tophi or soft tissue tophi) and arthrocentesis would show needle-shaped, negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals, gout can be ruled out.
Image Description:

X-ray of a left foot (AP and lateral views)

Joint space narrowing of the first metatarsophalangeal joint with multiple spiky periosteal appositions (green overlay). Both the first metatarsal bone and the first proximal phalanx also show the characteristic “punched-out” lesions (green arrowheads). There is marked soft tissue swelling on the lateral border of the foot (red overlay).

E) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the meniscal and hyaline cartilage on x-ray is typical of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), which can manifest with chronic inflammatory arthritis of the peripheral joints and morning stiffness. However, CPPD does not commonly manifest with constitutional symptoms, and the absence of the characteristic positively birefringent rhomboid crystals on arthrocentesis makes this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (AP view)

Calcification (green overlay) is seen within the menisci and articular hyaline cartilage of the medial and lateral compartments of the knee.

The chondrocalcinosis was the result of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate disease (CPPD).

F) CORRECT:

Joint space narrowing, marginal erosions of the cartilage and bone, generalized osteopenia, and subchondral cysts are typical x-ray findings in patients with RA. These findings usually appear late in the disease course. In early disease, soft tissue swelling and juxtaarticular osteopenia may be seen. Underlying joint disease, especially RA, is a risk factor for septic arthritis. This patient's septic arthritis is most likely caused by an asymptomatic, disseminated gonococcal infection (new partner, gram-negative diplococci in synovial fluid). X-ray is typically unremarkable in early septic arthritis but may show soft tissue swelling, gas within periarticular soft tissue, and synovial effusion.
Image Description:

X-ray right and left knee (AP view)

Joint space narrowing involves both the medial and lateral compartments (arrows and lines). Mild valgus deformity is present bilaterally. Bilateral osteopenia and periarticular erosions (green overlay in magnification) are seen. There is relatively little subchondral sclerosis or osteophyte formation (example indicated by red overlay).

In contrast to osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis typically involves the non-weight-bearing portion of the knee joint. Joint space loss involves all compartments and there is a comparative lack of subchondral sclerosis and osteophytosis. Joint effusion may accompany synovial inflammation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fever, joint pain, restricted range of motion, and arthrocentesis findings showing green turbid fluid, increased WBC count, and gram-negative diplococci, all of which are characteristic of septic arthritis. Symmetric joint pain, swelling of the finger joints and knee, morning stiffness > 30 minutes, and constitutional symptoms suggest an underlying diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), in which characteristic x-ray findings would be expected.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain and stiffness in both of her hands for the past 3 weeks. The pain is most severe early in the day and does not respond to ibuprofen. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows swelling and tenderness of the wrists and metacarpophalangeal joints bilaterally. Range of motion is decreased due to pain. There are subcutaneous, nontender, firm, mobile nodules on the extensor surface of the forearm. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is the first-line disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) for patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). It slows progression of the disease, preserves joint function, and limits complications, and therefore, should be initiated as soon as a diagnosis of RA is made. However, it takes ≥ 6 weeks to take effect. This patient requires fast-acting symptomatic relief for her acute flare.

B) INCORRECT:

The biologic adalimumab is used in patients with rheumatoid arthritis who still have moderate or severe disease activity after 3 months of DMARD therapy. It would not be used as the initial management of an acute flare.

C) INCORRECT:

Colchicine is used to treat gout and pseudogout, both of which can present with acute flares of joint pain. However, these conditions generally present with monoarthritis and/or asymmetrical joint involvement. Gout, which is often triggered by a large, purine-rich meal, or alcohol consumption, typically affects the metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe, the knee, and the thumb. Pseudogout typically affects the knee joint in elderly patients, and is associated with conditions such as hemochromatosis and hyperparathyroidism.

D) INCORRECT:

Sulfasalazine is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that is typically used in pregnant patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). However, it takes ≥ 6 weeks to take effect. This patient requires fast-acting symptomatic relief for her acute flare.

E) CORRECT:

Glucocorticoids like prednisone act rapidly to reduce symptoms of severe acute flares of RA. A short course of glucocorticoids has been shown to be more effective than NSAID therapy in reducing joint tenderness and pain and can be used to bridge the period until DMARDs, which are prescribed on a long-term basis to control disease activity, take effect.
questions.hint: This patient has classic signs of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), including morning stiffness, subcutaneous rheumatoid nodules, and swelling of the wrist and metacarpophalangeal joints. Her current symptoms are likely due to an acute flare of the disease.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has no other history of serious illness. Menopause occurred 1 year ago. Current medications include antirheumatic drugs and hormone replacement therapy. She exercises regularly. A DEXA scan shows a T-score of -1.80, indicating decreased bone density. Which of the following drugs is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sulfasalazine is a nonbiologic DMARD used to treat a variety of inflammatory and rheumatological conditions, including maintenance therapy for rheumatoid arthritis. Common side effects of sulfasalazine include headache, rash, and GI disturbances. Sulfasalazine is not known to decrease bone mineral density.

B) INCORRECT:

Medroxyprogesterone acetate is a medication most commonly used as a contraceptive agent. It mimics progesterone and can cause reversible bone mineral loss at high doses. This patient is postmenopausal, making it unlikely that medroxyprogesterone acetate is the etiology of her decreased bone mineral density.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal ulceration and renal insufficiency are the most common adverse effects seen with chronic NSAID use (e.g., naproxen, ibuprofen). While NSAIDs are commonly used in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, they are not known to decrease bone mineral density.

D) CORRECT:

Patients with refractory rheumatoid arthritis are frequently prescribed glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone), which induce bone resorption and increase the risk of osteopenia and osteoporosis. Glucocorticoid-induced bone resorption is primarily mediated via the RANKL signaling pathway, a cascade that upregulates osteoclast activity and induces apoptosis of osteoblasts. Chronic glucocorticoid use can also induce mild hypocalcemia, which leads to PTH-mediated bone resorption. In addition, decreased estrogen levels following menopause increase this patient's risk for osteoporosis and osteopenia.

Bisphosphonates and denosumab (anti-RANKL antibody) are used to treat glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis.
Image Description:

Features not specifically highlighted as being caused by inhaled glucocorticoids or by both systemic and topical glucocorticoids are caused primarily by systemic glucocorticoid use.

E) INCORRECT:

Adalimumab is a biologic drug used to inhibit TNF-α in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. TNF-α inhibition has immunosuppressive effects and is commonly used for refractory RA. Common side effects of TNF-α inhibitors include dermatitis, GI disturbances, and opportunistic infections. Adalimumab is not known to decrease bone mineral density.
questions.hint: This patient's DEXA scan indicates osteopenia. Other adverse effects of the drug responsible for this patient's osteopenia include hyperglycemia, peptic ulcers, and fat redistribution.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of low-grade intermittent fever, dyspnea, and chest pain that worsens on deep inspiration. Over the past 4 weeks, she has had pain in her wrists and the fingers of both hands. During this period, she has also had difficulties working on her computer due to limited range of motion in her fingers, which tends to be more severe in the morning. Her temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F). Physical examination shows a high-pitched scratching sound over the left sternal border. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?

choices.text: Increased titer of anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the HFE gene causes hemochromatosis, which can manifest with symmetrical polyarthralgias. Hemochromatosis-related cardiomyopathies, such as dilated cardiomyopathy and restrictive cardiomyopathy, may occur, but acute pericarditis is not a feature of hemochromatosis. Moreover, this patient lacks other features of this condition, such as diabetes, hyperpigmented skin (“bronze diabetes”), and cirrhosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated BUN levels indicate uremia, typically secondary to chronic kidney disease (CKD). Uremia can cause pericarditis, and bone pain may be present as a consequence of CKD-mineral and bone disorder (CKD-MBD). However, the bone pain in CKD is generalized in nature. Moreover, this patient lacks other signs of late-stage renal failure, such as edema and oliguria.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased C3 complement levels are typical in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE is a female-predominant disease and can manifest with symmetric small joint arthralgia, morning stiffness, and pericarditis. However, lupus-associated arthralgias are migratory in nature and joint stiffness would not be prolonged, usually lasting only minutes. Moreover, this patient is lacking other features of SLE, such as a malar or discoid rash and oral ulcers.

D) CORRECT:

Anti-CCP titers are used to diagnose rheumatoid arthritis. The sensitivity of anti-CCPs is similar to that of rheumatoid factor (∼ 60%) and their specificity is higher (> 90%).

E) INCORRECT:

Coxsackie virus RNA on PCR is diagnostic for a coxsackie infection. The picornavirus coxsackie B is the most common cause of viral pericarditis. Coxsackie infection may be accompanied by generalized arthralgia and myalgia. It does not commonly manifest with small joint arthritis and morning stiffness. Moreover, this patient's arthralgia began weeks before her symptoms of pericarditis.
questions.hint: This patient is most likely presenting with acute pericarditis (chest pain, dyspnea, high-pitched scratching heart sound) following a month-long history of symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis (symmetrical small joint pain of the wrists and fingers, morning stiffness).

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive pain and stiffness in her hands and wrists for the past several months. Her hands are stiff in the morning; the stiffness improves as she starts her chores. Physical examination shows bilateral swelling and tenderness of the wrists, metacarpophalangeal joints, and proximal interphalangeal joints. Her range of motion is limited by pain. Laboratory studies show an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following findings?

choices.text: IgG antibodies with a TNF-α binding domain on the Fc region
HLA-DQ2 proteins on white blood cells
Membrane proteins that bind to the Fc region of IgG
HLA-B27 protein on white blood cells
HLA-A3 proteins on white blood cells
IgM antibodies against the Fc region of IgG

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Etanercept is a fusion protein that fuses the IgG Fc domain to a TNF-α receptor. This drug binds and inhibits TNF-α and is used in refractory therapy for chronic inflammatory systemic diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis). In rare cases, etanercept might cause an allergic reaction with swelling of the hands, feet, and ankles. However, this reaction would not be characterized by arthralgia and morning stiffness, which this patient has. Additionally, while etanercept is used to treat RA, this patient does not report taking any at the moment.

B) INCORRECT:

HLA-DQ2 proteins on WBCs are found in celiac disease, in which hypersensitivity to gluten triggers the production of autoantibodies against tissue transglutaminase in the small intestine. Celiac disease can manifest with a mildly elevated ESR and arthritis, which this patient has. However, arthritis in celiac usually affects the lumbar spine, hips, and knees. Celiac disease may also include symptoms of malabsorption (e.g., vitamin deficiencies and fatigue, and in some individuals weight loss, abdominal pain, or diarrhea) and possibly hormonal or skin complications such as dermatitis herpetiformis, which this patient does not report experiencing.

C) INCORRECT:

Protein A is a virulence factor located on the membrane of S. aureus. It targets the Fc region of IgG and protects the bacterial cell from opsonization and phagocytosis. S. aureus can cause septic arthritis and would correspond to an elevated ESR. However, this type of arthritis is typically monoarticular and most commonly affects the knee, hip, wrist, shoulder, and/or ankle. Additionally, septic arthritis would not manifest with morning stiffness, but rather with symptoms of systemic infection such as fever.

D) INCORRECT:

The HLA-B27 protein on WBCs is found in seronegative spondyloarthropathies, a group of chronic inflammatory arthritic diseases that can manifest with symmetrical oligoarthritis, morning stiffness that improves with movement, and an elevated ESR. These symptoms are also seen in this patient. However, she does not have the cardinal sign of seronegative spondyloarthropathy – slowly progressive pain in the lower back and sacroiliac joints (especially at night).

E) INCORRECT:

HLA-A3 proteins on white blood cells would be increased in hemochromatosis, a condition caused by an autosomal-recessive defect in the HFE gene. Hemochromatosis can manifest with symmetrical arthropathy of the second and third MCP joints, where this patient also has pain. However, this patient does not have the bronze skin tone or any typical complications (e.g., diabetes mellitus, hepatomegaly, liver cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy) seen in hemochromatosis. Furthermore, ESR would not be elevated in hemochromatosis.

F) CORRECT:

Rheumatoid factors (RF) are a group of IgM autoantibodies that target the Fc region of IgG. Although elevated RF is classically associated with RA, it has low specificity, since RF elevation may be physiological or caused by other autoimmune and infectious diseases. The level of RF in serum typically increases over the course of RA.

A more specific serological parameter for RA is anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies (ACPA).
questions.hint: This middle-aged woman has classical symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). She has morning stiffness that improves with activity and polyarticular arthritis (indicated by swelling and tenderness) that involves small joints but spares the DIPs. In addition to non-specific parameters (e.g., increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate), a classic serological finding in some patients is the rheumatoid factor.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 42 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I am tired and my joints hurt.”
History of Present Illness:


fatigue, myalgia, and joint pain over several years
joint pain rated 5/10 at worst

neck pain at rest most mornings, lasting more than an hour
occasionally wakes up at night with tingling in the right volar hand and thumb


Past Medical History:

no recent medical care in over a decade due to limited health care coverage
generalized anxiety disorder

Medications:
citalopram
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
mother and father alive with no chronic conditions
Psychosocial History:

has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years

does not drink alcoholic beverages
not sexually active

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.8°C(98.2°F)
87/min
14/min
142/85 mm Hg
164 cm(5 ft 5 in)
90 kg(198 lb)
33 kg/m2




Appearance: no acute distress
HEENT: conjunctival pallor; thyroid gland is normal in size with no mass or tenderness
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Musculoskeletal: flexion of proximal interphalangeal joints of bilateral index fingers with hyperextension of distal interphalangeal joints; tenderness and swelling in metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints of both hands and metatarsophalangeal joint of right 1st and 2nd toes

Neurologic: shooting pain along the right upper neck and shoulder with tilt and rotation of the neck toward the right side while applying downward pressure to the head

Diagnostic Studies


Blood



 Hemoglobin
10.1 g/dL


 WBC
4,200/mm3



 Platelet count
345,000/mm3



 ESR
42 mm/h



Testing for which of the following serum parameters is most likely to yield a positive result?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticentromere antibodies are associated with limited systemic sclerosis (SSc). While limited SSc can manifest with arthralgia, myalgia, and constitutional symptoms, this patient has none of the characteristic features of this condition, such as calcinosis cutis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia. Anticentromere antibodies are not associated with RA.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and can be found in 60–70% of affected individuals. SLE is more common in women and can manifest with distal symmetric polyarthritis, myalgia, neuropathy, anemia, and leukopenia. However, joint deformities are uncommon in SLE, and peripheral neuropathy is more likely than radicular neuropathy in these patients. Finally, additional symptoms consistent with SLE such as photosensitivity, Raynaud phenomenon, and/or a malar rash are absent in this patient. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are not associated with RA.

C) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibody (ANA) testing is commonly used to screen for autoimmune diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), certain types of inflammatory myopathies. ANAs are only elevated in 30–50% of patients with RA and are thus not a particularly useful screening test. A different serum study is more likely to be elevated in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor (RF) along with anticitrullinated peptide antibodies (ACPAs) are the most sensitive markers for RA and are present in 60–80% of patients. High RF and ACPA titers are also associated with a more aggressive disease course (e.g., erosive arthritis or extraarticular manifestations, such as rheumatoid nodules and Felty syndrome). The presence of RF is not specific for RA, however, and may also be seen in other autoimmune disorders (e.g., Sjogren syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatic fever), certain infectious diseases (e.g., parvovirus B19 infection, infective endocarditis), chronic liver disease, and even in 3–5% of healthy individuals. Approx. 30% of patients with RA are negative for ACPA and RF, referred to as seronegative RA.

See “Serological testing in rheumatoid arthritis” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Mi2 antibodies are myositis-specific autoantibodies highly specific for dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis manifests with progressive symmetrical proximal muscle weakness and distinctive skin findings (e.g., Gottron papules, heliotrope rash), neither of which this patient has. Anti-Mi2 antibodies are not associated with RA.
questions.hint: Symmetric polyarthritis affecting the MCP, MTP, and PIP joints, along with Boutonniere deformities of bilateral index fingers, and features of cervical radiculopathy (due to atlantoaxial subluxation) strongly suggest rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue), compression syndromes (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome), and anemia of chronic disease are common in patients with RA.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents with mild dyspnea and a chronic, nonproductive cough. She describes herself as being in good health, has never smoked, and has undergone all age-appropriate cancer screenings.
Her vital signs are unremarkable, and her oxygen saturation is 95% while she is breathing ambient air. A chest radiograph shows a moderate left pleural effusion but no other abnormalities.
A diagnostic thoracentesis aspirates a thin-appearing, light-green fluid. Analysis of the fluid yields the following results:


pH
7.00


Lactate dehydrogenase
2998 U/liter


Total protein
3.7 g/dL


Total glucose
<20 mg/dL


Leukocyte count
356 per mm3



Erythrocyte count
433 per mm3



Gram stain and acid-fast bacilli smear are negative for organisms. However, slender, elongated, spindle-shaped cells are noted.
Which one of the following additional physical examination findings is this patient most likely to have?

choices.text: Synovitis of the metacarpophalangeal joints and subcutaneous nodules
Cracked skin of the lateral aspects of the digits
Scattered, seborrheic keratoses over the chest and back

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Among unselected patients with rheumatoid arthritis, 5% will develop a pleural effusion during their lifetime. Twenty-five percent of effusions precede or appear simultaneously with joint symptoms. Aspiration yields a sterile, nonbloody, exudative fluid with a markedly low glucose level and a pH that is often below 7.30. On cytology, the classic triad of findings comprises (1) slender, elongated macrophages; (2) round, giant macrophages; and (3) necrotic debris. Metacarpophalangeal joint synovitis and subcutaneous nodules will be evident on physical examination.

Key learning point: A sterile, exudative pleural effusion with a markedly low pH and spindle-shaped cells on cytology is a common pulmonary manifestation of systemic rheumatoid arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Cracked skin of the lateral aspects of the digits is evident in patients with antisynthetase syndrome, who are more likely to develop parenchymal abnormalities than pleural disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Digital periostitis is the classic finding of psoriatic arthritis, which is not associated with the development of pleural disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Digital clubbing suggests chronic hypoxemia, which is rare without concurrent interstitial lung disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Scattered, seborrheic keratoses over the chest and back (Leser-Trélat sign) are associated with occult malignancy. Although malignant pleural effusions are also exudative, cytology demonstrates malignant cells in >50% of cases, and they tend to be grossly bloody.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman reports a 2-day history of pain over her right elbow. She does not recall any specific trauma to the area. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis treated with prednisone 5 mg daily.
On examination, her temperature is 37.1°C, her heart rate is 94 beats per minutes, and her blood pressure is 115/81 mm Hg. Her elbow is erythematous and warm to the touch. There is an effusion overlying the olecranon bursa. The patient can fully extend her elbow without increased discomfort, but pain is elicited with passive flexion of the elbow. None of her other joints is tender or swollen. There are rheumatoid nodules over the forearms, and there is ulnar deviation of the fingers.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient's evaluation?

choices.text: Obtain a CT scan of the elbow
Increase the dose of prednisone to 60 mg daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Imaging studies, such as CT, are not typically helpful in the setting of a nontraumatic, acute olecranon bursitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Initiating treatment with colchicine would only be appropriate for gout, which is unlikely in this patient and would require proof by aspiration in any case.

C) CORRECT:

The olecranon bursa can become inflamed from an infection, crystalline disease, or other systemic disease that causes an inflammatory arthropathy. Septic olecranon bursitis typically causes acute pain, erythema, and warmth of the affected elbow. Fever and leukocytosis are common but not universal. Progression to joint infection or septicemia can occur if an infection is not identified and treated properly.

When the cause of acute olecranon bursitis is not apparent, fluid aspiration from an acutely inflamed bursa is warranted because it can distinguish an infection from a noninfectious inflammatory etiology. The bursa fluid should be sent for cell count, differential, Gram stain, culture, and crystal analysis. The cell count in septic bursitis is usually much lower than in septic arthritis, so an initial finding of only mild inflammation does not rule out infection. Serial drainage of a septic bursa may be necessary to clear the infection.

Key learning point: The primary evaluation of acute olecranon bursitis consists of aspirating the bursa and sending the fluid for cell count, differential, Gram stain, bacterial culture, and crystal analysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing the dose of prednisone is not appropriate because although a rheumatoid arthritis flare can cause bursitis, it would be unlikely to cause an isolated olecranon bursitis without other joint involvement.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism in most cases of culture-proven septic bursitis. Treatment with antibiotics such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole alone is often inadequate without proper drainage.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman with a 6-month history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with worsening joint pain. At the time of her diagnosis, she reported several months of pain and swelling of multiple metacarpophalangeal joints and proximal interphalangeal joints, along with both wrists. At that time, she was noted to have high titers of rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies, and hand radiography revealed erosion on her left third metacarpophalangeal joint.
Treatment with oral methotrexate was started shortly after diagnosis; she has had few adverse effects, and the dose has been increased to 25 mg weekly, along with daily folate. She reports an improvement in symptoms but continuation of pain and swelling, along with 90 minutes of stiffness each morning.
On examination, her second and third metacarpophalangeal joints are swollen, warm, and tender bilaterally. Her wrists are tender at the joint line, are swollen, and have limited range of motion.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a C-reactive protein level of 8.80 mg/liter (reference range, 0.08–3.10) and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 42 mm/hr (1–25).
What change in therapy is most likely to be effective for this patient?

choices.text: Stop the methotrexate and initiate a tumor necrosis factor inhibitor
Continue the methotrexate and initiate a tumor necrosis factor inhibitor
Stop the methotrexate and start sulfasalazine
Increase the methotrexate dose to 30 mg weekly
Stop the methotrexate and start leflunomide

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When a patient has persistent features of active rheumatoid arthritis despite maximum-dose methotrexate therapy, the most appropriate management is to add any one of several approved biologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) or targeted synthetic DMARDs to the patient’s current regimen. Combination therapy with methotrexate and a TNF inhibitor has been shown in clinical trials to be more effective than either medication alone.

B) CORRECT:

When a patient has persistent features of active rheumatoid arthritis despite maximum-dose methotrexate therapy, the most appropriate management is to add any one of several approved biologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) or targeted synthetic DMARDs to the patient’s current regimen.

Biologic DMARDs

• Anti-interleukin-6 receptor monoclonal antibodies (tocilizumab, sarilumab)
• Anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody (rituximab)
• Anti-cytotoxic T-lymphocyte antigen-4 fusion protein (abatacept)
• Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors (etanercept, infliximab, adalimumab, certolizumab pegol, golimumab)

Targeted synthetic DMARDs

• Janus kinase inhibitors (tofacitinib, baricitinib, or upadacitinib)

For this particular patient, the most appropriate next step in therapy (of the options listed) is to add a TNF inhibitor to the background methotrexate. Combination therapy with methotrexate and a TNF inhibitor has been shown in clinical trials to be more effective than either medication alone. Before starting any biologic DMARD or targeted synthetic DMARD, patients should be screened for latent tuberculosis and for viral hepatitis, which can reactivate when biologic or targeted synthetic DMARDs are started.

There are also other approaches to escalating therapy that should be considered in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis who is not responding optimally to methotrexate alone. Since the absorption of oral methotrexate varies from about 50% to 90% and becomes less efficient above 20 mg, the route of administration can be switched to subcutaneous injection. Alternatively, adding both sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine to methotrexate (i.e., triple therapy) can be as effective as adding a TNF inhibitor, as demonstrated in a major clinical trial. Triple therapy may be preferred in lower-resource settings as well as in patients with comorbidities for whom triple therapy may be associated with a lower risk of adverse events.

Key learning point: An appropriate next step in therapy for a patient with rheumatoid arthritis that is flaring despite maximum-dose methotrexate therapy is to add a tumor necrosis factor inhibitor.

C) INCORRECT:

Stopping methotrexate and starting sulfasalazine or leflunomide would not be optimal in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis that has not responded well to maximal doses of oral methotrexate. Sulfasalazine has modest clinical efficacy and is unlikely to provide benefit as monotherapy in a patient whose rheumatoid arthritis has not responded to full methotrexate doses.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing the dose of oral methotrexate above 25 mg weekly provides no additional benefit, because higher doses have been shown to increase toxicity without improving clinical effectiveness.

E) INCORRECT:

Stopping methotrexate and starting sulfasalazine or leflunomide would not be optimal in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis that has not responded well to maximal doses of oral methotrexate. Leflunomide is similar to methotrexate and would not be expected to improve control of this patient’s rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man reports a 3-month history of progressive pain and stiffness in both hands and wrists. He works as a mechanic. Every morning, he has stiffness for approximately one hour. He also reports severe fatigue but no fever, trauma, travel, preceding illness, sexual activity outside his monogamous marriage, or recreational drug use. He has been using naproxen, which provides minimal relief.
On physical examination, the patient is afebrile and has normal vital signs, normal heart sounds, a clear chest, and no rash. He has tenderness on palpation and swelling of the wrists and the second through the fifth metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. His other joints are nontender. He has normal strength, a normal skin examination, and no numbness, oral ulcers, or alopecia.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a normal urinalysis, complete blood count, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Tests are negative for rheumatoid factor, antinuclear antibody, anti-citrullinated peptide antibody, anti-Ro antibody, anti-La antibody, anti-double-stranded DNA antibody, anti-Smith antibody, antiribonuclear protein antibody, and antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody. Tests for hepatitis B and hepatitis C are negative. Cryoglobulins are not detected.
Radiographs of the hands and feet reveal no deformities or erosions.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis may also involve the back as well as the large joints in the lower extremities, and peripheral articular manifestations often include enthesitis, dactylitis, or both. Furthermore, reactive arthritis often includes extra-articular manifestations, such as psoriasiform skin lesions, eye inflammation (uveitis or conjunctivitis), urethritis, or a preceding episode of illness, including gastrointestinal infection (e.g., with Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, or enteroinvasive Escherichia coli) or genitourinary infection (e.g., Chlamydia).

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus can manifest with inflammatory polyarthritis, but rash, cytopenias, or other abnormalities are usually present. In the absence of a syndrome highly suggestive of lupus, a negative test for antinuclear antibodies rules out the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Spondyloarthropathies are always important to consider in a patient with seronegative inflammatory arthritis. However, ankylosing spondylitis always involves the sacroiliac joints and usually the lumbar spine and therefore manifests with back pain.

D) CORRECT:

The 2010 American College of Rheumatology criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis are based on joint involvement, duration of symptoms, and levels of rheumatoid factor, anti-citrullinated peptide antibody (ACPA), and acute-phase reactants. Patients with synovitis in >10 joints lasting >6 weeks in whom there are no alternative diagnoses meet criteria for rheumatoid arthritis even if they have normal results on serologic testing and normal acute-phase reactant levels. Seronegativity for rheumatoid factor and ACPAs is seen in approximately 20% of patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Deformities and erosions typical of rheumatoid arthritis can still develop in such patients, who may need aggressive treatment. In those with early rheumatoid arthritis, plain radiography of the hands often shows no erosions.

Key learning point: The percentage of patients with rheumatoid arthritis who have negative tests for rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies is approximately 20%.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibromyalgia is characterized by widespread pain, unrefreshing sleep, daytime fatigue, and memory or cognitive issues without evidence of synovitis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents for follow-up for her erosive rheumatoid arthritis, which is being treated with etanercept and methotrexate. She also has hypertension. She is scheduled to undergo an elective cholecystectomy for recurrent biliary colic and gallstones in one week. The procedure will be done laparoscopically with general anesthesia and endotracheal intubation.
The patient has no chest pain or dyspnea. Her vital signs are normal, as are her neurologic, cardiac, and pulmonary examinations. Her musculoskeletal examination reveals ulnar deviation of both hands, with swan-neck deformities of the digits.
Which one of the following tests is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the neck would be indicated to determine extent of cervical spine disease in a patient with dynamic cervical spine instability on flexion/extension radiographs or in a patient with myelopathic findings on neurologic examination. It is not a preoperative requisite in all patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

B) CORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) can cause cervical subluxation, most often in the atlantoaxial joint. Subluxation results from laxity of the transverse ligament induced by proliferative synovial tissue at C1–C2 or from erosions or fracture of the odontoid process. Symptoms include pain, neurologic deficits, and deformity of the neck. Neurologic findings are detected when the space available for the brain stem, spinal cord, or nerve roots is compromised. Risk factors for cervical spine instability in patients with RA include long-standing disease, erosions, elevated inflammatory markers, and seropositivity for rheumatoid factor, cyclic citrullinated peptide, or both.

Although imaging for cervical spine instability is not routinely recommended in asymptomatic patients with RA, it is warranted in those who are planning to undergo endotracheal intubation because the neck manipulation required for intubation may be fatal for those with unrecognized cervical instability. The preferred imaging in this setting is cervical spine radiographs with flexion and extension views.

Key learning point: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis who are planning to undergo elective surgery requiring intubation should first undergo radiographic evaluation of the cervical spine with flexion and extension views.
Image Description:

MRI cervical spine (T1-weighted; sagittal view) of a 64-year-old woman with a 12-year history of rheumatoid arthritis and increasing neck pain for 3 months

There are erosive changes to the odontoid process (dens; D). The distance between the dens and the anterior arch of the atlas (A) is widened due to (inflammatory) tissue proliferation ventrally to the dens (green overlay), causing posterior subluxation of the dens. This, in turn, has led to narrowing of the spinal canal between the dens and the posterior arch of the atlas, causing compression of the spinal cord (red overlay).
A syrinx is seen at C5–C7 (yellow overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with rheumatoid arthritis are at increased risk for cardiovascular events, but screening echocardiography is not recommended for asymptomatic patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis may be associated with pulmonary involvement (such as organizing pneumonia, interstitial lung disease, or pleural effusions), but screening pulmonary function testing and chest radiography are not suggested for an asymptomatic patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis may be associated with pulmonary involvement (such as organizing pneumonia, interstitial lung disease, or pleural effusions), but screening pulmonary function testing and chest radiography are not suggested for an asymptomatic patient.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man with rheumatoid arthritis presents with recent onset of oral ulcerations, mild nausea, and dyspepsia. He denies genital ulcerations. He was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis one year ago based on joint pain and swelling, a positive rheumatoid factor, and a positive anticitrullinated protein antibody. He was started on prednisone and methotrexate with folic acid, and his joint symptoms improved; he now appears to be in remission on methotrexate monotherapy. He reports no weight loss or melena.
On examination, the patient looks well. He has several ulcers on his tongue and buccal mucosa along the bite line. He has no abdominal tenderness, organomegaly, or mass. A swab of one of the lesions is negative for herpes simplex virus.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Confirm adherence to folic acid supplementation
Obtain a biopsy of an oral ulcer

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydroxychloroquine is generally less effective for rheumatoid arthritis than methotrexate. Assessing for nonadherence to folic acid is therefore more appropriate than replacing methotrexate with hydroxychloroquine, because reinitiating folic acid could allow for continuation of the more effective therapy.

B) CORRECT:

Methotrexate, a folate antimetabolite that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, is a first-line disease-modifying antirheumatic drug for patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Its use is sometimes limited by toxicity and adverse effects, including oral ulcers (particularly in areas of repeated trauma, such as the bite line of the buccal mucosa), hair loss, cytopenias, liver function test abnormalities, and gastrointestinal symptoms.

In a 2013 systematic review, folic acid supplementation in patients taking methotrexate was found to significantly reduce the incidence of gastrointestinal side effects and abnormal serum aminotransferase levels; a trend toward reduced incidence of stomatitis did not reach statistical significance. Most authorities recommend that all patients taking methotrexate adhere to supplementation with folic acid, folinic acid (leucovorin), or both. In this patient who was appropriately advised to take folic acid, confirmation of adherence to the supplementation would be the first step in management.

Key learning point: Oral ulceration and gastrointestinal symptoms are common adverse effects of methotrexate therapy and should be prevented and managed with supplementation with folic acid, folinic acid (leucovorin), or both.

C) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate should not be discontinued unless adverse effects are refractory to supplementation with folic acid, folinic acid, or both.

D) INCORRECT:

Conservative measures should be attempted before pursuing a biopsy because the diagnosis of methotrexate-induced oral ulceration is highly likely in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids are appropriate only for treating oral ulceration that is due to inflammatory disorders, such as Behçet syndrome, vasculitis, or pemphigus.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is evaluated for progressive fatigue. He was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis about 10 years ago, when he presented with bilateral hand and wrist pain. He declined medical treatment and has instead used herbal remedies, engaged in chiropractic manipulation, and followed a holistic diet. He reports no other medical problems and takes no medications other than his herbal remedies. He reports no fever, chest pain, cough, weight loss, dyspnea, travel, or contact with sick people.
Physical examination reveals normal vital signs. There is no lymphadenopathy or rash. His chest is clear to auscultation, and his heart rate is regular. On abdominal examination, the spleen is palpable but nontender. His bowel sounds are normal. Musculoskeletal examination is significant for severe deformities in the hands with ulnar deviation, and swan-neck or boutonniere deformity in all digits. He has palpable nodules on the extensor surfaces of both elbows.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
13.5
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
150,000
150,000–350,000


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
2100
4500–11,000


Neutrophils (%)
20
40–70


Lymphocytes (%)
70
22–44


Monocytes (%)
10
4–11


Eosinophils (%)
0
0–8


Band forms (%)
0
0–10


Anti-citrullinated peptide antibody
Positive at high titer
Negative


Rheumatoid factor (IU/mL)
1290
<30


Antinuclear antibody
1:160
Negative at 1:40 dilution


Anti-double-stranded DNA, anti-La antibody, anti-Ro antibody, anti-Smith antibody, and anti-RNP antibody tests are all negative. Serum and urine protein electrophoresis do not show a monoclonal band. A peripheral-blood smear shows leukopenia, normal lymphocytes, and no schistocytes or blasts. Bone-marrow biopsy reveals myeloid hyperplasia, with a relative excess of immature forms.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Felty syndrome consists of the triad of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), neutropenia (an absolute neutrophil count <2000 cells per mm3), and splenomegaly. The overall lifetime risk for Felty syndrome among patients with RA is about 1%, although recent studies suggest that this condition is becoming even rarer, perhaps as a result of improved RA therapies. Patients with untreated, aggressive, and seropositive (rheumatoid factor and/or anti-citrullinated peptide antibody) disease are at highest risk. Patients with Felty syndrome are more likely to have extraarticular manifestations, such as vasculitis, mononeuritis multiplex, necrotizing skin lesions, pleuritis and/or pericarditis, rheumatoid nodules, lymphadenopathy, and episcleritis. Patients with Felty syndrome have an increased risk for infection due to neutropenia. Bone marrow often shows an arrest of maturation of granulocytes, as seen in this patient.

Key learning point: The triad of rheumatoid arthritis, neutropenia, and splenomegaly is characteristic of a diagnosis of Felty syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Caplan syndrome consists of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis and usually manifests as pulmonary nodulosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus can manifest as cytopenia; however, this is typically accompanied by other signs of lupus, such as a malar rash or proteinuria, and usually by specific autoantibodies to specific nuclear antigens rather than only a positive antinuclear antibody.

D) INCORRECT:

Myelofibrosis is unlikely in this case; the bone-marrow and hematologic findings are not consistent with this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Large granular lymphocytic (LGL) leukemia is a clonal lymphoproliferative disorder manifested by lymphocytic infiltration of peripheral blood and bone marrow. Like Felty syndrome, it may also cause neutropenia and splenomegaly. Up to one-third of patients with LGL leukemia may have RA, but it can also be associated with other autoimmune conditions. The peripheral smear in LGL leukemia often shows elevated lymphocyte counts, and the bone marrow shows infiltration of lymphocytes, which were not present in this case. Somatic mutations in the STAT3 gene have been found in patients who have LGL leukemia associated with RA. Traditionally, the distinction between Felty syndrome and LGL leukemia has been made on the basis of clonality; those in whom there is a polyclonal expansion of lymphocytes are defined as having Felty syndrome, whereas those with monoclonality are defined as having LGL leukemia. However, recent studies suggest a similar immunologic basis for both conditions and support the view that they represent a spectrum of condition rather than distinct entities.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man reports a 4-month history of pain and swelling in the hands and wrists, hand stiffness that lasts up to 2 hours each morning, swelling and stiffness in the elbows and knees, and fatigue. He also describes being awakened at night by numbness and paresthesias in both hands, primarily in the thumbs and in the second and third digits. He has no rash, no previous history of pain or swelling in any joints, and no significant alcohol intake. He works as an automobile mechanic and notes that his grip has become weak. He has taken occasional doses of over-the-counter naproxen without much benefit. His current vital signs are unremarkable.
Which one of the following physical examination findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Swelling and tenderness of the proximal interphalangeal joints
Thickening of the palmar fascia with flexion contractures of the digits
Swelling and tenderness of the distal interphalangeal joints
Isolated tenderness and swelling of tendons overlying the radial side of the wrists without any articular abnormalities.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by joint swelling, joint tenderness, and joint destruction. RA typically causes synovitis at the wrists, metacarpophalangeal joints, and proximal interphalangeal joints but may also involve larger joints. RA rarely affects the distal interphalangeal joints, which helps to distinguish it from osteoarthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and gout.

This patient’s numbness and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerves is consistent with bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, which is often seen in RA patients who have wrist synovitis and tenosynovitis of the flexor tendons. A patient presenting with carpal tunnel syndrome alone (i.e., in the absence of RA) would be more likely to have unilateral hand involvement and would not likely report hand swelling, morning stiffness, and fatigue. Carpal tunnel syndrome is not typically associated with other causes of inflammatory arthritis, such as psoriasis or gout.

Key learning point: A patient with new-onset rheumatoid arthritis is most likely to present with synovitis at the wrists, proximal interphalangeal joints, metacarpophalangeal joints, and flexor tendons.

B) INCORRECT:

Dupuytren contracture (thickening of the palmar fascia resulting in flexion contractures and therefore stiffness of the fingers) does not have an established association with rheumatoid arthritis and would not explain most of this patient’s symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:
